text: Adding #testthat tests to your #rstats package helps with proper regression testing. But @_lionelhenry’s #vdiffr package extends this functionality even further, allowing you to test for regressions in visuals such as #ggplot2 plots! #rstats #tidytuesday https://t.co/bfPLbGcWBm

For my Thanksgiving #TidyTuesday exploration, I tried to use market basket analysis to uncover association rules for thanksgiving dishes and then compare those rules community types. Not perfect, but it's something! https://t.co/6Eh9RrFb1W https://t.co/nXz05Aczje

Extending the analysis on the #TidyTuesday dataset, for winery-varieties having more than one taster, I analysed the skew in the number of times each taster was involved and whether they had a significant impact on the mean points for the winery #rstats https://t.co/vnRym47AMV

This week I continued to play around with labels, using them to point out particular events not covered in the original article. As you might expect, presidential activities bring media coverage to natural disasters, but particularly when paper towels are involved. #TidyTuesday https://t.co/D9krHSGglP

With #TidyTuesday's state level house price index data, I looked at how each state has changed since the housing crisis. Percentages are calculated w/ each states lowest HPI divided by their 2018 HPI. 
Should have put money into Nevada real estate! 
Code: https://t.co/AcduYkXWmJ https://t.co/mLhgRkClZj

For today's #TidyTuesday I have been playing with strings... I tidied the @BoardGameGeek data to separate out the categories into a single factor and then pulled out a few interesting pairings to look at the popularity of these game types over time. 1/n https://t.co/YSnSx5KUIl

#TidyTuesday Week 2019/24: "How many meteorites have fallen to Earth in the last decades? Which were the heaviest of them?"  with data provided by @NASA <U+2604><U+FE0F>
Got inspired by #90s #SciFi blockbusters and had much fun creating this #dataviz! <U+0001F913>

Having some fun with #tidylo, a new package from @juliasilge for log odds ratios! Here we’re taking a look at popular baby names specific to the 1990s, 2000s, and 2010s. Curious about decades prior? Follow along with Julia’s blog! https://t.co/l90P9uFtCH #rstats  #tidytuesday https://t.co/Pcb0wmVrIn

#TidyTuesday on #TardyThursday In the greater Chicago Area: number of collisions and species colliding in September, October, and May have been rising since about 2000.  Not the case for McCormick Place collisions. I am guessing data collection methods play at least some role. https://t.co/0IWG2uf5gz

Did you know that #dplyr includes a set of special #tidyverse-compatible ranking functions? Here we show min_rank(), percent_rank() (re-scaled to [0, 1]), cume_dist() (CDF), and the base::cut()-like ntile() function! #rstats #tidytuesday

See more here: https://t.co/1sO5ssusQj https://t.co/M52Kpr6pQS

I am this ancient geek (e.g. love greek-roman mythology), so what a joy to re-start #TidyTuesday after my vacation. I learned a lot about emperors!

Looked into age of death.
If you did not die in battle, you committed suicide or you were killed (commissioned by your wife). https://t.co/4ephh5EX19

@R4DScommunity Inspired by a  visualisation from @GuardianData, I plotted the gender pay gap for Australia for this week's #TidyTuesday challenge. Looks like things aren't much better in Australia. Interesting how the biggest pay gaps are for jobs where women earn more than men. https://t.co/k12gYMz3zS

For this week's #TidyTuesday #rstats #dataviz, I tried text mining on #anime synopsis and created a #WordCloud from 3 million common words. <U+26C5><U+FE0F> Pretty happy with the result. <U+2764><U+FE0F><U+0001F970> Lets take a look of the Anime world. <U+0001F4FA><U+0001F47E>

#TidyTuesday #TidyLater #Housing #InspiredbyTidyTuesday I've gone off menu for this week's challenge.  fredr is a package that will connect you to FRED data and FRED has all of the data. I'm looking at how housing prices in NYC have changed over the past 30 years https://t.co/dLa7kPMKHY
